multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following is the best definition of a quiver in the context of this article?
choices: A mathematical expression representing evolutionary relationships.
A directed graph where vertices represent species and edges represent evolutionary descent.
A table listing the characteristics of different species.
A branching diagram showing the evolutionary relationships between species.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is an "evolutionary chain" in a quiver?
choices: A sequence of vertices connected by edges, representing a possible lineage.
A property of a vertex that determines its position in the evolutionary hierarchy.
The set of all possible descendants of a given vertex.
A vertex with a single ancestor.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does it mean for two vertices in a quiver to be "isotypic"?
choices: They represent species with identical genetic makeup.
They have the same number of ancestors.
They are descendants of each other.
They occupy the same position in the evolutionary tree.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which statement about "primitive vertices" is TRUE according to the article?
choices: Primitive vertices have no descendants.
A quiver always has a unique primitive vertex.
All ancestors of a primitive vertex are also primitive.
Primitive vertices represent extinct species.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the "height" of a vertex in a quiver signify?
choices: The number of generations that have existed since the appearance of that species.
The shortest evolutionary path from a primitive vertex to that vertex.
The number of descendants a particular vertex has.
The complexity of the genetic makeup of a particular species.
